reviewText: I saw this movie in 1978 when I was a kid, and just discovering Tolkien and the world of heroic fantasy, and I absolutely LOVED it.  I didn't get to see it again for about ten years, and by then I was a much more critical audience.  I still found it good, but by then I was well able to notice the flaws.Looking at it today, I still like it, but it could have been so much better.  Prior to CGI effects, there simply wouldn't have been any way to bring Tolkien's Middle Earth to the screen in a live action version.  The huge battles, and some of the more fantastic creatures couldn't have been done with the special effects of the time, not very well anyway.  Unfortunately, it has to be said that Bakshi didn't do any better answering some of those same challenges.  The rotoscoped live actors of the battle scenes just don't fit in with the rest of the animation, and are too obviously guys in rubber masks.  The Balrog, as it appears in this film, is also quite obviously just a rotoscoped guy in a very cheesy-looking suit.  Disney animators (whatever else they might have done, for good or ill) would have made the Balrog as spectacular and frightening as one could have wished for.  The only animation that really looks good in this movie is that of the main characters (and even there, Aragorn looks a little too much like an Apache for my taste).But in truth, the problems with this film are mostly of the technical sort.  The voice acting is really quite good, and both the action and the characterization are actually far more faithful to Tolkien's novels than in the Peter Jackson movies.  In the scenes in the Shire, in the Inn in Bree, the Council of Elrond, and all throughout the film, Bakshi used Tolkien's dialogue almost unaltered (parts were edited out to keep the film's run time from being overlong, but what was used is pretty much just as Tolkien wrote it), whereas Peter Jackson and co. rewrote almost every line of dialogue spoken by every character.  Bakshi portrayed Pippin and Merry just as Tolkien had portrayed them: as trusty, stalwart companions, whereas Jackson turned them into a couple of half-witted buffoons played for comic relief, and even a bit of bathroom humor in one scene.  Bakshi made Theoden a valiant warrior king (after being healed by Gandalf), whereas Jackson made him weak-willed and indecisive at Helm's Deep.  Bakshi made Aragorn the hardy, wayworn ranger, fulfilling his destiny just as Tolkien had shown him doing, whereas Jackson portrayed hims as running from his responsibilities until his hand was forced.  Bakshi, in portraying the scenes at the Prancing Pony inn at Bree, the Council of Elrond, Boromir's final battle, and other scenes, played out the action just as it was in the books, whereas Jackson made considerable changes.And Jackson made more and more changes to Tolkien's narrative with each film.  As the great reviews poured in following Jackson's "The Fellowship of the Ring", the second and third films showed progressively more tendency on the part of Peter Jackson to put his own stamp on the saga, featuring increasingly severe deviations from the original story in the books.  I don't insist that every novel brought to film be made absolutely 100% faithful to the original story -- indeed, oftentimes that's not possible, as film is a very different medium.  But most of the changes Jackson made were simply not improvements to Tolkien's original story, and there's no reason why the original could not have been filmed closer to the way it was written.  After all, Bakshi did it more than twenty years earlier, and those were the parts of his film that worked the best.  The flaws in the animated version come from elsewhere.So I still appreciate this movie as a partly successful attempt to bring Tolkien's magnificent epic to filmgoing audiences.  Bakshi's faithfulness to the original story is what makes this film watchable.  The animation is very hit-and-miss, and there are legions of things one can see that could have and should have been done better, but fans of J.R.R. Tolkien's work should appreciate what's here for the good that's in it.  Peter Jackson's treatment is far more famous and successful, and deservingly so, by and large, for it is a great work, which I enjoyed immensely.  Nevertheless, there are aspects of the story that Bakshi told better, and viewers ought to recognize that.
summary: A pretty good attempt at bringingTolkien to film audiences.

reviewText: OK let's start by saying that this is NO comparison to the fantastic recent trilogy of movies by Peter Jackson, and it is animated (I'll come back to that) but it is still a good movie. Considering the year of production for a second, director Ralph Bakshi had a vision, and the same kind of idea as Jackson, but without the backing, the money, or the technology to carry it off. The film follows the book very closely, and those having watched the new movies will see and hear identical scenes in this version, lifted straight from Tolkeins pages. The idea was to make TWO movies (but not simultaneously) which means this is a little muddled in mixing books 1&2, made with the obvious expectation of a sequel.The animation is mixed with a process called rotoscoping (traced over live action integrated into cell animation)in a surreal fashion in places which adds much in the way of atmosphere, and certainly makes the dark armies appear more menacing. This idea of animation was more than a little groundbreaking at the time, even though it was done chiefly to save money, and annoyed more than a few puritans in the business. Sadly this movie went down like a lead parachute at the box office, and with it went Bakshi's backing for the second film, and knowing this means you are expecting an anti climax of sorts. The DVD has little in the way of extra's, but the budget price certainly makes it worth owning. Repeated viewing does get you inside the directors vision, and obvious love of the material, and one could argue that had this been made 20 years later, Peter Jackson & Co may have been out of work, Enjoy this Cult and Collectible Classic at a great price.

reviewText: I have very dull memories of this film from when I was a kid. I feel that the only way I can explain my opinion is a brief history of my connection to the books. Otherwise it's not clear where I'm coming from. I first sawThe Hobbitwhen I was about 8. I was immediately hooked and read all the books. Of course, I was 8 so I had a great deal of trouble remembering what was going on. The fact that Aragorn changed his name three times did not help at all. So while I knew the basics of the story a great many details had eluded me. Upon finishing the books I naturally wanted to see the movie. So the next time my family went to the video store (yes VHS. I'm that old) I immediately chose that film to watch.My memories of it are somewhat fuzzy, which was my reaction at the time as well. I had a hard time following the film even though I'd seen the book. It seemed fragmentary and portions of it were so far from the way I imagined them that they didn't make sense. Being used to the more unique style of the Hobbit I was somewhat disappointed by the more realistic look of the animation. When the film ended right in the middle of the books... well, as you can imagine I was pissed. Although by that point I was bored and confused. My brother (who hadn't read them) was even worse off. So years later when the new films came out I was as excited as I could be.For a while I've been meaning to watch this film again, to see how it compares with my memories of it. I rewatched the Hobbit too, a film that held up a LOT better. So my review is based off of this viewing with bits of my old memories filling in what it feels like for a child watching it. I would like to start with the good things that I didn't remember but there really is something else I have to cover first: the animation. I remember not liking the animation as a child but I had thought it was more a stylistic thing than a quality one. But the animation here is really terrible. I understand that a lot of this is budget related but it's still hard to watch. Large portions of the film are rotoscoped. Worse than that there are large portions which are filmed with actors in terrible costumes and just run through a filter to make them look less real. As a whole the effect is inconsistent and ugly. Just plain ugly. When they actually bother animating them the characters look good. I particularly liked the look of Frodo, a look I remember hating as a child.So, about the characters. Some of them are quite good. But many of them are bad. Really bad. Rather more are unmemorable and generic. I'll deal with the good ones first. As I said, I rather liked Frodo. I felt he captured some aspects better than Elijah Wood, who I also loved. This Frodo spent less of his time looking all teary eyed and was more assertive and a more active participant in his fate. The biggest problem with him is that the animators like making him twitch around like a child, possibly due to his size. Aragorn is also quite good. I know the Nostalgia Critic preferred this Aragorn to the one from the new films, and while I wouldn't go as far as that I can see why. John Hurt is excellent in the role. His Aragorn is more noble and stoic than Viggo Mortenson's and seems less wild, while still embodying the rough and ready ranger. His performance is all the more impressive because he has some really hard lines to deliver. He's probably the only one who is UNDER-animated. Gandalf is quite good as well. He also suffers from mysterious arm spasms every time he talks but his voice is calm and measured. Sometimes he waves around out of sync with what he's saying which is quite weird. I still prefer John Huston's Gandalf from the Hobbit or Ian McKellen's from the new films. Saruman is quite good as well, despite the writers' attempts to destroy him. They call him Arriman to distinguish him from Sauron except when they forget and call him Sarimun which makes it more, not less, confusing. Galadriel is less creepy than Cate Blanchett, which is nice. I think she's the only character I actually like better in this version. Gimli is barely in it but what little you see of him is quite good. For some reason he's as tall as the rest of the men, which is odd to say the least.The bad: Sam is dreadful. Period. He's a crazy, stupid peasant. It's absolutely horrible. He has no dignity whatsoever. Elrond and the elves in general look just like humans. Given that they weren't limited by makeup limitations this is especially perplexing. Treebeard sounds perfect but he looks like a strange kind of turnip. The enemies (except Saruman) are all done poorly. Sauron looks even sillier than he does in the Jackson version with his giant horned helmet. The Dark Riders have all the menace of a cripple in a cloak. First off, they're not black. More a light grey. Second, they jerk around like they're crippled. And then sometimes they just turn into people wearing horned costumes with glowing red eyes. The orcs are always people in costumes who waddle like fat drunks in Halloween costumes. Their only noticeable attribute is their giant fangs. The Balrog looks like a winged lion. It also flys around, which makes me wonder why it lets itself fall into the pit. There is nothing ominous about any of these designs. I don't like Gollum either. He's astonishingly low key and very slow. Not a threat at all. Oddly his animation tends to be better than those of the other characters. Another odd thing which affects all of the characters is that they like to roll their r's a lot for no good r-r-r-rrrrreason!And the mediocre take up most of the cast. There are a lot of characters in the Lord of the Rings. Often times they don't even bother introducing the characters. Merry and Pippin are indistinguishable. And if the creators don't bother why should anyone else care to differentiate them? Bilbo is barely in it at all since it starts with him leaving which gives him no time to make an impression before he leaves. The funniest scene with him in is when he's "tempted" by Frodo's ring, by which I mean he has a random seizure while looking at it. The hobbits generally look like little children, which makes me wonder if the animators decided to make them look like children because they're the size of children. Legolas actually looks different from humans in the way no other elves do. His eyes are tilted at a steep angle which makes him look rather etherial and nonhuman. He's also voiced by Anthony Daniels (C-3PO) who sounds even more effeminate than Orlando Bloom's Legolas. Honestly, I don't really like elves anyway so maybe others will like him better. Theoden is... there. That's all I can say about him. Boromir leaves very little impression except that he's a Viking complete with horns and giant beard. Strangely enough he left a bigger impression on me as a kid than he did the second time around. I remember him literally pinned to the tree with arrows but it turns out that it wasn't like that at all. Which is strange because I have such a strong memory of it. As a whole the character designs are more Anglo-Saxon than high medieval, which seems more fitting for the humans than the elves. Tolkien might have liked that better though since he worked a lot on the Anglo-Saxons. Problem is, the Saxons never built anything like the huge cities or vast armies he describes, which makes the world seem small and underpopulated.Going back to the animation, the background plates are terrible. They're under-detailed and hideously colored. The whole film has a strange color scheme in fact. Sometimes it is decent enough but other times it goes into monochromatic mode for no discernible reason. When using live actors especially the background vanishes and is replaced by shades of red or grey. It is all very ugly. The magic tends to be accompanied by crazy sparkles and flashing lights which reminds me why so many '80s fantasy films failed. Saruman actually shoots balls of light at Helm's Deep. It seems to me that when you need to sell something extraordinary you do it by making it seem ordinary, not by adding a lot of flashy lights as if to shout "Ooh! Magic happening here!." The music in the film is rather good, even though they almost never use it. Often when they do use it it seems out of place too, as if they felt there should be music so they just stuffed it in.It was a mistake to combine these books into one film. There are a series of climaxes that never match the natural flow of the film. As it gets closer to the end this problem gets worse. The plot leaps forward at a breakneck pace which skips over much essential information to reach the battle of Helm's Deep in time for a final battle before the film ends. As the audience for this film went in expecting to see the whole story played out the ending of the film in the middle of the second book is a massive letdown. That's my main memory of the film and it's still valid. The ending is abrupt and surprising. Plotwise they are rather more loyal to Tolkien than the Peter Jackson films were. Timelinewise there are very few discrepancies to the book. They achieve this by often jumping from one scene to the next with no transition. They actually skip most of the council of Elrond and when they reach Lothlorien they jump right from talking in the forest to Galadriel's hall. But while the timeline is better, the world itself is off. Badly off. From the little details that Jackson & Co did so well to the constant changes to the lore this film changes a lot. While Jackson's film feels like it takes place in Tolkien's universe this movie takes place in some dimly lit and strangely unfocused and primitive world which could never be mistaken for any sort of reality.So that's the movie. There are some good things in it, but they are well hidden. It's not positively bad but it is silly and uninteresting. Anyone interested in seeing this world on film is of course infinitely better off watching the newtrilogy.The Hobbitis an excellent adaptation in a different style, designed for children. I grew up on it so I find most of its flaws nostalgic. AvoidThe Return of the Kinganimation. It's far worse than this one. It's done by the same people who did The Hobbit unfortunately, and their childish style doesn't fit well at all with the more adult subject matter. Thebooksare of course beyond amazing.
summary: Better Than I Remember But Still Pretty Bad

reviewText: Ralph Bakshi's 1978 vision of the first half of Tolkien's trilogy respects the spirit of the written work.  I saw this when it first came out and was pretty disappointed, so I was curious to watch it again.  I have to say it's not horrible, and there are some interesting foreshadowings here as well.  Some of the scenes are repeated faithfully by Peter Jackson; animation over live action, which works well for the Dark Riders but not so well anywhere else, is Waking Life 25 years early; and the Dark Riders look a lot like Lucas's sand people in A New Hope.  Things are cut.  Lots of things are cut.  But after having a 20-year dry spell between filmmakers taking a crack at Tolkien, you've got to appreciate the attempt.The screenplay is well written and faithful to Tolkien's ideas.  Bakshi wisely drops the songs (The Hobbit really suffers from the dated schmaltzy singing) but the soundtrack is still a weakness here -- a very 70s orchestrated feel, like Peter Gunn with hairy feet.  Animations of the hobbits were a little bit weird-looking but certainly not the worst I've seen.  In general the animation style is heavy and dark, so the elven lands suffer.  John Hurt's voice for Strider doesn't really work for me personally, but William Squire does a nice voice for Gandalf, and the others are fine. This is a fine effort and definitely worth watching for Tolkien or animation fans.Extra features include a few screens of minimal information about Tolkien, the cast & crew, and the races of Middle Earth.The best feature on the disk is the incredible number of available subtitles -- English, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Chinese, Japanese, Thai and Korean!  Awesome.
summary: limited but respectful adaptation and subtitles galore!

reviewText: Let's get one thing straight. I don't like to brag, but I know my Tolkien. I was read the hobbit before I knew what "ire" and "break of day" meant, and LOTR followed soon after, at the tender age of six. When I first heard that a movie had been made of my favorite book of all time, I had to see it. Unfortunately, Bakshi didn't know how to handle the material.The problem lies in that this movie tried to be a translation of Tolkien's book, only condensed into two two-hour movies. The first one, The Lord of the Rings, falls flat because of how it is presented, not the story.Fortunately, the story here is intact. Of course there were ample numbers of things that were cut out, but the events play out as written, and the dialogue is straight from the pages. Problem is, all that jazz doesn't matter if you don't know HOW to tell a story. That's the difference between the Peter Jackson version, and the Bakshi version. Jackson knew HOW to tell the story; Bakshi did not.Firstly, the main characters all look ridiculous, even for a cartoon. The hobbits look more like kids than little people, Sam is turned into the immensely stupid comic relief, Legolas, a WOOD ELF (you know, with the whole BLEND IN thing) prances around the whole movie in glaring white, and Boromir, a lord of the most advanced human civilization in Middle-earth, is drawn as A FREAKING VIKING. No. Just NO. Additionally, Bakshi chose to use rotoscoping (tracing over live actors to make them look cartoony) and it looks awful, even compared to the regular animation.There were other things that were changed for unimaginable reasons. Sauruman is changed to Auruman, though some of the characters still use the original name, which is confusing as heck. The blasting fire of Orthanc comes in the form of fire works which strike the Deeping Wall at Helm's Deep. And the Balrog *cringe* FLIES. Only once mind you, when it's NOT hurtling down a black abyss. These things were just jarring and ugly.The one real asset to the movie (and the only reason this review is getting any stars at all) is the voice actors. They all do a wonderful job, but those most notable are John Hurt as Aragorn and Anthony Daniels (yes Star Wars geeks, C-3PO) as Legolas. Really, all the voice work is excellent, and the Tolkien dialogue comes off sounding quite believable when spoken. Again, the story is commendable, but the presentation is rancid.Which boils down to why it is NOT a good idea to go for a complete translation of books when making a movie. Not enough time was spent in how to display the world or its people, and there were some really dumb things Bakshi did to the characters.All in all, if you're a die-hard-dyed-in-the-wool Tolkien geek and want to see ALL things Tolkien, this may be stomochable now that we have a decent version of the LOTR trilogy around. However, when I see it, my reaction is the same as it was when I first saw the cartoon at age seven: "What in the world were they thinking?"I can only be thankful that the planned second movie was never made.
summary: Why Translation Is NOT The Way To Handle LOTR

reviewText: Looking for a worthwhile movie to give my 7-year-old nephew for Christmas, I considered, but then ruled out Peter Jackson's version of The Lord of the Rings, which I felt would be at too mature a level for a little boy.  I wondered if this earlier, animated version would be suitable for him and would appeal to him.  When I saw that several reviewers out of the more than 300 here on Amazon's site had liked it when they were young boys, and when I saw that some people who'd seen it as adults also felt it was a laudable movie, I ordered it.  I thought that if I viewed it and found it unsuitable for my nephew, I might enjoy it for myself, being a fan of Lord of the Rings.Although I've now viewed it, and I do think it would be a good movie for a child, and so I'm going to give it to my nephew as a gift, I only half liked it for myself.What I really LIKED very much was the Backgrounds and Settings, which I thought were outstandingly beautiful, with very artistic design quality, coloration, and dramatic light-play:  Think of the most beautifully illustrated children's book that you ever enjoyed--or even a beautifully illustrated adult story by certain artists--for instance, something comparable to the illustrations by E. McKnight Kauffer for the Random House version of Green Mansions--and the backdrops of this movie would qualify for that category of excellence.(I would take exception, though, to the opening scene of the movie which portrayed the historical flashbacks that set the story-line, all taking place in silhouette against a plain red background.  That scene became visually boring because it went on far too long.  It was the first thing that caused me to begin to downgrade the movie.)What I DISLIKED about this movie were the Animation and the Characters that were portrayed by this animation.  I found these elements of the film disappointing.  The animation was very unattractive visually, and I felt the animation was done shallowly and too simplistically.  The characters were just caricatures without the depth of characterization that came through in Peter Jackson's dramatization of Tolkien's story.I felt that the characters' voice-characterizations were not very outstanding either.I particularly disliked the silly characterization in this movie of the otherwise very important character who was Sam.Although I wasn't disturbed by the effect of the "rotoscoping" technique, which some other viewers found unsuccessful, I was very disturbed by the effect of superimposing the animated action upon the gorgeous artistic backgrounds.  Since I associate the animation technique with cartoons and with Disney re-tellings of more childish fairy tales than was The Lord of the Rings "myth," I perceive animation as having a trivializing effect.  The mixing of the artistic backdrops and the animation technique just struck me as inappropriate.Anyway, great "sets" or not, the animation technique turned me off.  I disliked the choice to use it for Tolkien's trilogy such as it eventually developed after incorporating elements of "The Hobbit," originally a children's story for which animation might have been a more appropriate technique, but, overall, I think the animation of "The Lord of the Rings" subtracts from the dignity, depth, and magic of Tolkien's written story such as it finally ended up being.  (But, similarly, I've sometimes wondered if Tolkien's story itself didn't also suffer from an inappropriate admixture of children's tale with epic myth, and also from the oddly intermingled worlds of the child-sized, earthy Hobbits and the other more usual-sized, heroic, intermarried human-like and elven creatures of Middle Earth.)About the "rotoscoping" technique by which realistic shots of actors were obscured and added into the animation somehow, it occurs to me that I actually found that effect of obscured realism to be attractive when it occurred in this movie.  It looked quite alright superimposed upon the background artistry.  I think it might actually have been a better and more suitable idea to have done the entire movie in the rotoscoped technique rather than the animation.This much-abbreviated version of Tolkien's trilogy, by contrast with Peter Jackson's later lengthy portrayal, contains no romantic themes at all, and it ends with the battle at Helms Deep.

reviewText: Although it is inevitably overshadowed today by Peter Jackson's films, Ralph Bakshi's animated version of "The Lord of the Rings" is actually quite good.  For one thing, the screenplay is a superb adaptation of roughly the first half of the tale (part II never materialized, thanks to financial difficulties) - it is intelligent and literate, simplifying the plot where necessary but not diluting it too much.  The voice work is outstanding (notably John Hurt as Aragorn and William Squires as Gandalf), and Leonard Rosenman's score ranks among the finest of its era.  I'm sure that Bakshi's decision to capture a fair amount of the action via "rotoscoping" (tracing over live-action images) was motivated, at least in part, by financial considerations, but in all honesty I can't see how he could have done some of the big battle scenes otherwise (not much computer animation happening in 1978). In any case, if you view the film with an open mind, you'll find that the technique distracts far less than the hard-liners would have you believe.  For me, anyway, it cannot materially diminish the quality of such a fine adaptation of Tolkien's unforgettable novels.  Of course, Peter Jackson's films are in an entirely different league, but I still regret the fact that Bakshi never got to finish his version of the story.  I think his vision was and is a compelling one, and I'm sorry he never got to see it through to its conclusion.
summary: A valiant early effort - give it a chance!

reviewText: When I was 7, my Aunt Bobby took me to see Ralph Bakshi's animated Lord of the Rings at the Zigfield Theater in Manhattan. I will always remember sitting in that cavernous theater, watching the amazing story of Middle-Earth unfold, and just generally being amazed by the lushly colored animation on the gigantic screen. The characters and locales look pretty much as one would imagine from reading the books. (This movie adapts The Fellowship of the Ring & half of The Two Towers.) I had a problem with Strider and Boromir trudging through feet of snow in nothing but their little dresses, though.....bundle up, guys!The scenery is by turns lush (The Shire), and forbidding (The excellent Mines of Moria sequence). The problems were pretty much all the same: Bakshi's use of "Rotoscoping", or filming real actors and drawing over them. The rotoscoped portions just don't fit with the rest of the movie, and it can be QUITE jarring to look at. Also troubling (in a very minor way...) was how "Saruman" was pronounced "Aruman" about half the time. People who aren't familiar with the story will find that confusing; people who ARE will find it more and more irritating each time it happens......and it happens A LOT. The film also ends a little too abruptly; I remember being bothered by that as a kid. (It still bothers me!)On the plus side, the DVD looks great; the colors are perfect, and the sound is great. It's too bad there aren't more extras: all there is are a few text features. (Not even a trailer!)Overall, not as good as the new film adaptation, but worth a look for Tolkien fans.

reviewText: Long before Peter Jackson ever got the go-ahead to depict a live-action "Lord of the Rings" movie, Ralph Bakshi gave it a fair stab.And by "stab," I mean he made a rotoscoped, animated movie that attempted to encompass half of JRR Tolkien's classic epic. It's a genuine effort with obvious affection, but unfortunately Bakshi misses the mark more often than he hits it -- from the bizarre character designs to random renamings.The movie starts (after some background info) several years after Bilbo Baggins gets a golden Ring of invisibility. At Bilbo's 111st birthday party, he vanishes with intent to leave the Shire -- and Gandalf sees that Bilbo is exhibiting signs of falling under its power. He convinces Bilbo to leave the Ring with Bilbo's young cousin, Frodo, and then leaves.Seventeen years later, Gandalf reappears and tells Frodo that it is the One Ring, and that Frodo now has to leave the Shire (accompanied by his gardener Sam and cousins Merry and Pippin), heading off to the town of Bree and then to Rivendell. Unfortunately, Frodo soon is pursued by the snuffling Black Riders, and accompanied by the mysterious ranger Aragorn. Worst of all, he's being tempted by the Ring -- and it nearly costs him his life.Then he volunteers to take the Ring into the dark land of Mordor to destroy it -- but the Fellowship of the Ring must deal with horrors and terrors along the way. And when they lose two of their company, Frodo sets out into the wilderness with only Sam beside him, while Aragorn, the elf Legolas and the dwarf Gimli set out to free Rohan from the evil Saruman (or "Aruman," depending on what scenes you watch).I'll give Bakshi credit -- he put genuine effort into trying to turn "The Lord of the Rings" into a two-part movie. Unfortunately for him, the second part never materialized (the movie clangs to a stop halfway through the second book) and the first one is an awkward, uncertain piece of work that never quite figures out where it's going.And the animation simply doesn't work -- the characters all have exaggerated gestures and shuffling walks, not to mention odd costuming (a Viking? A Roman senator?). The backgrounds tend to look like matte paintings, and the rotoscoping is bizarre-looking and distracting at best.The animation is not the only problem. Bakshi's movie is riddled with very choppy editing (we go straight from Moria to Lothlorien), bizarre script changes ("Saruman" becomes "Aruman") and important details that are left out, or left in with no explanation as to why they are there. Worst of all, he has little idea of what looks absurd -- the bat-winged lion-Balrog with its big fuzzy feet is a legendary example, as well as the virtually crippled Black Riders and turnip-shaped Treebeard.Nor does he succeed with the characters. The mellow young Frodo, skeletal Gollum and ethereal-looking Legolas are well done. But Gandalf acts like a manic old weirdo, and most of the others (especially Merry and Pippin) are barely more than cardboard cutouts. The worst offender is loyal, steadfast gardener Samwise Gamgee -- who looks and acts like a brain-damaged, potato-shaped chimp."The Lord of the Rings" was a valiant effort that fell flat on its face somewhere along the way. Watchable as a curiosity, but nowhere near the scope of Peter Jackson's masterpiece.

reviewText: I first saw this film in 1978 when I was 13 years old and I loved it. I was a fan of Tolkien's literature (even though at the time it seemed a bit complex and confusing to me) before I saw the film. After having seen it, Bakshi's The LOTR fueled my imagination of Tolkien's world further by giving me a solid visualisation of it, and a partial rendering of it's story. My love and understanding for Tolkien's work and world has grown considerably over the years as I've matured. I'm 35 years old now and I still love this film when I watch it.I believe that the only valid criticism surrounding this film is criticism that comes from viewers who have read, understood, and are able to retain what they have read of Tolkien's literature (which rules out 75% of the fans of the Peter Jackson mega-budget film(s)), and who had initially seen this film in 1978/1979. Why? Because this film is based upon the most complex mediaeval-fantasy literature ever written, and shouldn't be viewed the same way as Harry Potter or The Chronicles Of Narnia. And because it was a different time back then; films were different, animation was different, special effects were different, perception was different, and culture was different. As well, one needn't read the books to enjoy this film; but one does need to read the books, and retain what one has read to understand and appreciate it.The most common complaints I've heard and read about this film are ones I would like to address. The most frequent complaint registered is that Bakshi edited out far too much of The Fellowship Of The Ring. Well of course he had to, didn't he? He was, after all, combining four books equalling two novels into one film for the cinema--not an easy achievement, especially if you're one who is familiar with the complexity of the books. (The only way to fully achieve a significant translation of Tolkien's The Lord Of The Rings would have to be in the form of a mini-series made for non-commercial television. Anyone interested?) As well, people complain about the film ending only half way through the story of The Lord Of The Rings. What they fail to understand is that another film based on the unfinished parts of The Two Towers and The Return Of The King was to follow. But Bakshi was denied the funds to produce it, so unfortunately nothing materialised. Another complaint is of the animation itself: rotoscoping. Rotoscoping is a technique of filming live actors and then drawing and painting directly over their images on the film to achieve an eerie realism. How can anyone say that the movements are unnatural when they are taken directly from live actors? I'll wager these same critics who say such an ignorant thing think that the computer-generated Cave Troll and Balrog in Jackson's film look and move realistically. Bakshi's animation is marvellous and breathtaking in this film, and he makes use of many creative and innovative techniques--even if they aren't all that pleasing to each individual set of eyes that view it.Bakshi's The Lord Of The Rings follows Tolkien's literature and dialogue with great respect. With a few exceptions, like Merry making the travel with Frodo, Sam, and Pippin across The Shire to Buckleberry, the Hobbits hiding all together in an alcove off the road whilst a Black Rider hovers above them (a scene Jackson stole from Bakshi), and Legolas meeting Aragorn and the Hobbits instead of Glorfindel, Bakshi only edits Tolkien's story and does not make significant changes to it (like Jackson does). Bakshi even throws in a few original things of his own, which add to the overall viewing pleasure.The voice talent in this film is absolutely superb, and is very characteristic to the personas of the people involved.As far as the physical character designs, and with the exception of the Hobbits not having curly hair, as well as the crude design of Aragorn, Bakshi's animated portrayals are right on (or very close to) the mark. I even accept Boromir's Nordic/Viking apparel and appearance as representative of Gondor strength--(after all, Tolkien loved stories about Vikings and had even formed a Viking Club with certain aquaintances and colleagues of his where they would get together in a local pub and read stories about Vikings to one another).Musically, Leonard Rosenman's original score is wonderfully fitting, and the best I've ever heard from him.The film's pacing and editing is actually very good--although does get a bit muddled towards the end, as befits the literature. I think people who may complain about the latter are forgetting that this is an adult fantasy story, and not a child's; and that it wasn't designed directly to appeal to those with a short attention span.Ralph Bakshi's The Lord Of The Rings with all its many faults and mistakes, nevertheless remains the only respectfully definitive work based on Tolkien's story put onto film thus far; much more so than Peter Jackson's dazzling live-action comic book-screenplay version (which, despite my criticism, I also love). Bakshi's The Lord Of The Rings is for the pure of heart fan of Tolkien's literature. Although it may not satisfy your appetite, it will certainly whet it.
summary: Truer to Tolkien's literature than Peter Jackson's film(s).

reviewText: I haven't seen this movie in a while, so I'm afraid I can't be very specific about details... It did have some interesting points. Ralph Bakshi's attempt at an animated adaptation of J.R.R Tolkien's masterpiece was a very ambitious project, so ambitious in fact that it went bankrupt at some point during the production. Therefore, not only does it stop abruptly somewhere around the middle of the second book of the trilogy (with sort of a shade of a hint of a sequel that was never made), the film itself seems less than finished. It seems that some characters were animated while others were filmed, but whether or not it's intentonal is hard to say. The whole thing seems shabbily made and undone, especially the Orcs and the Nazgul. Another problem, of course, is the huge gaps in the plot. Bakshi was in a rush to finish this movie, and he somehow hoped to cram a book and a half in little more than two hours (the new trilogy by Peter Jackson does it in about twice that time.) Far too many important bits were left out (and I don't refer only to Tom Bombadil, which, I think, was lovely in the book but would look silly in a movie.) And of course, the ending, which is completely sudden and out of place. I'm not even sure if Bakshi originally intended to end the film there, or if he even had any idea where he's going to end it.The characters... well, most of them were okay. The hobbits don't look so bad (except for the gay Sam. Did you know that the producers of the new trilogy originally wanted to make Sam a woman so there would be a faminine lead character?) If you're a Tolkien fanatic (like me), watch this movie (though I'm not too sure about buying it. What special features does the DVD version have, anyway?) But know in advance that you're not going to watch a real 'Lord Of The Rings Movie' but not much more than a historical curiosity, which probably looks not much better than the 60s version would have had the Beatles carried on with their plan (I actually think a psychedelic LOTR could have been quite cool. The idea was to cast George as Gandalf, Paul as Frodo, Ringo as Sam and John as Gollum.) If you didn't read the book or didn't like it much or don't like animation films or don't want to see a half-finished movie... stay away.

reviewText: Having seen this film first in '78 in the theaters I was blown away and turned on to the work of Ralph Bakshi (already being a fan of Tolkien - this only fueled the fire more).  By the early 80's I was able to purchase a VHS copy of this (for $80+ - ouch) which I still own and use to make friends and family their own copies since this baby is out of print. Sure there are parts that don't quite jive with the books but Bakshi is much closer to the mark then 1979's ROTK (orcs are an aberration of elves not a lump with a huge maw and no body - and Casey Kasem's voice in Tolkien - GOD HAVE MERCY!). Moria is exactly how I imagined, and I still get chills when the black riders unveil themselves at Bree (note the half-orc spy conversing at the table with his fellow spies at the prancing pony - very subtle) The animation is top notch (Bakshi has been animating since the 50's) and while some feel the rotoscoping takes away from the feel of authenticity, I personally feel it fits for the orcs and nazgul and is part of Bakshi's style.  This film is now being remastered for a DVD release to coincide with Peter Jackson's trilogy - which I have been anxiously waiting for. I heartily endorse anything by Ralph Bakshi - he is a true master of the craft (what a shame that he retired) and really captures the feel of the era in his films - try Fritz the Cat, Heavy Traffic, Coonskin (a real natural cotton sweater!), Hey Good Lookin', Wizards (why isn't this on DVD yet?), American Pop, and Fire & Ice (another wonderful fantasy film deserving of DVD release). reviewText: Long before Peter Jackson's now famous trilogy graced the silver screen, there were several animated adaptations of J.R.R. Tolkien's fantasy, one of which was this production by Ralph Bakshi. Of the three, Bakshi's version is the weakest, and an absolutely disastrous insult to Tolkien fans.The primary problem with this film is that tries to squeeze the first two and-a-half books in the trilogy into a two-hour production; in doing so, it sacrifices a great deal of the depth and complexity that made the original stories so appealing in the first place.  The movie speeds along at a dizzying pace that it never takes as much time to develop the characters as they should.  Even certain sequences which shouldn't be so important are dragged out much too long.More unforgivable is the quality of the animation, which is not only dreadful, but it looks even worse when Bakshi attempts to use "rotoscoped" techniques on many of the action scenes. (Such visuals are also out of place with the actual animation, too.)  It looks especially bad during the massive crowd scenes involving ogres, cloaked wraiths, and other denizens of Mordor.  That the character designs are also completely unattractive and the backgrounds lacking in detail and sophistication are also serious detriments to Bakshi's presentation.The resulting movie comes across as a jumbled, confusing mishmash that not only alienates the audience, but even stops before it actually finishes.  Following a confusingly staged and messy battle (Helm's Deep), a voiceover declares the audience that this is the end of the first part of the tale, but does so at a very inappropriate point.  There's no major resolution and the plot is left dangling.To its benefit, this LORD OF THE RINGS does have a powerful score by the late Leonard Rosenman and some decent voice work from actors such as John Hurt as Aragon. However, the aforementioned weaknesses overshadow them by far.Avoid this messy travesty at all costs and stick with Peter Jackson's trilogy--it may not be more "literal" in terms of the dialogue (another sole saving grace of the film), but they are miles better.
summary: A lesson in how NOT to adapt a respected trilogy.

reviewText: This film may not fit everybody's ideal interpretation of Lord of the Rings, but it gets a lot of things right. Another studio eventually made The Return of the King, which leaves a large gap in the overall story between the movies.The movie also has various quirks, such as referring to the character Saruman as "Aruman", to avoid confusion with Sauron.  At times, they forget and call him Saruman anyway, leaving the viewer even more confused. reviewText: Ralph Bakshi made this film too soon. Let's be honest here, 1978 was too early for such a subtle blend of animation and real action acting, not to mention a glorious sound track that defines the movie as a classic from beginning to end. We weren't ready for this film in 1978, it was too intellectual, too clever and too much for an audience used to films that didn't go over an hour and a half. Another minus is that it doesn't follow Tolkein's book in the way perhaps it should but it gives a good rendition of the story, and the characters of Frodo, Gandalf, Legolas and Gimli are well represented. I was a bit disappointed by the portrayal of Aragorn but John Hurt's voice certainly made up for that shortfall. The animation is superbly done; the grainy texture that divides the real actors from the animated ones also helps create a sort of three-dimensional setting that makes Middle Earth more believable. Add to this a good dollop of action, humor and romance and you have a wonderful film that really should have been made in the 1990s. Golum for example is wonderfully camp and creepy, and Sam Gamgee bumbles along but shows fortitude and courage in the most surprising places. The Ring Wraiths are quite terrifying, and their high pitched wailing chills your bones, as does the scene where Frodo is caught between the world of the shadows and the world of real people. Balroc and the Orcs are truly terrifying, and Gandalf is magnificent as the only wizard who understands the real danger than the "one ring" represents to all of Middle Earth. The scene-stealer for me is the great Eagle Guyiere lifting Gandalf from the top of the mountain where Saruman the White has imprisoned him. Look out also for the part where Frodo tries to flee to Rivendell, mortally wounded by a Ring Wraith's poisonous sword. There is so much in this film, and it is such a shame that it has been overlooked for so long. Like everyone else I am looking forward to the new Lord of the Rings film but Ralph Bakshi's animated classic will remain forever in my heart as the first attempt to make Tolkein's world come to life in a very unusual way.

reviewText: This is a long review, and I will even go so far as to apologize in advance to those of you who have a 1-minute attention span for reading reviews. I won't dwell very long on the faults of this movie because I'm certain others have done a fine job of it, but I will open with a couple of my biggest peeves.I don't know why this galls me so much, but most of the actors insisted on saying "Aruman" instead of "Saruman." I don't know if this was a weird sound clipping issue, a scripting typo, or a seriously misinformed consultant, but be aware of this if details bother you. There are also some other name mispronunciations (this must be the origin of the idea that people should say "SORE-aaahn" instead of Sauron). Also, it seems that Peter Jackson was not the first to modify characters for the "flight to the ford" sequence because a rather comical Legolas appears on the road after Frodo is wounded. Having seen both scenes now, I really would rather see Arwen speaking elvish than a large-eyed man who seems to have little sense of urgency for Frodo's recovery.Putting aside the plot details and pacing issues, people should actually consider other aspects of the movie for a moment (among book-to-film adaptations, LOTR fans seem particularly obsessive about accuracy to the books, but there are other things to look at). For one thing, I think it was impressive that a 2+ hour animated film (take note of that word: ANIMATED!) was finished at all. There are few animated movies I am willing to watch more than once, but this is near the top of my very short list.In my mind, the animation artists who worked on this movie - although their styles are rather dated at times - were plenty capable. There's generally a level of detail to facial expressions that even some Disney movies of the day couldn't beat. There are some remarkably subtle movements that make any and every character more lifelike, and this itself is a feat. There are, of course, some silly moments, but I find myself wanting repeat viewings in part because of the animation detail. Of equal note are the matte (background) paintings, which are generally gorgeous.The voice acting is generally marvelous and I can't think of many faults (except that after seeing the Peter Jackson version, the Merry and Pippin here seem too serious and Sam is embarrassingly fatuous and bumbling). The sound quality is about average for a movie of its age (the only 1970s movie I ever liked the sound on was "The Black Stallion," which excels in both sound quality and cinematography).Leonard Rosenman's score strikes me as nothing extraordinary, but capable for an animated feature. The cues are appropriate, as is their timing with the on-screen action. The music even has occasional moments of building greatness, such as the ending at Helm's Deep. The song "Mithrandir" in its choral goodness is quite pleasant as well (ignoring the fact that children aren't mentioned in Lorien). However, I'm going to ruffle feathers here and insist that Howard Shore's scores have so much more depth. Listen to Rosenman if you want to learn how to make an adequate old-style cartoon soundtrack; listen to Shore if you want your socks blasted off.To me, the problem with Bakshi's version isn't what it does or doesn't do as much as how very many things it TRIES to do. It looks busy because it IS busy - one thing you can't accuse him of is laziness. We have a mixture of visual styles (standard animation, rotoscoping, and tricks with light and colored smoke ON TOP OF the frames). We have sound effects just this side of being over-the-top. Of course, some of the "mixed media" techniques are due to an indignant production company that refused another budget allotment. It almost feels like there just wasn't quite enough time to percolate ideas.This adaptation is, in some ways, grittier than Peter Jackson's. This one, though peppered with some beautiful scenery, lacks the pastoral lushness of its 2001 descendant. There is far less humor in the Bakshi film, although the Bakshi version feels a little more scholarly than Jackson's at times, especially with regards to Gollum (who is brilliantly disgusting most of the time!).Is the Bakshi film flawed? Certainly, but I'm not going to spit in its face. Bakshi was a visionary and a pioneer any way you slice it, and this movie is brimming with evidence of it if you're willing to look past the picky details of the surface. He clearly cared for Tolkien's work or he would not have bothered making a full-length movie about it. Respect your elders! Without this version, Jackson might not have tried at all, or he might have made a spectacular failure. This version does as many things right as it does wrong. If you're interested in the impact of Tolkien's writing on pop culture, have patience for animation, and want to hear some GREAT voice acting, watch this film.
summary: Another piece of the cultural puzzle for LOTR fans and observers

reviewText: Ralph Bakshi, who was most well-known in the 1970s as the creator of the X-rated FRITZ THE CAT and HEAVY TRAFFIC went mainstream with THE LORD OF THE RINGS in 1978. Originally slated to be a two film project, Bakshi wanted to name this LORD OF THE RINGS PART I but was overruled by the studio execs. That should have been his first warning that there wouldn't be a PART II.The existing film includes material from "The Fellowship of The Ring" and "The Two Towers." Bakshi is faithful to Tolkien's work, even more so than Peter Jackson, though a few of his characterizations are off-key, such as Boromir, who is depicted as a Viking warrior.Come the end of LOTR you WILL be asking yourself, "Where's the third reel?" The film ends abruptly---really abruptly---disturbingly so. Merry and Pippin are carried off by Treebeard (who looks like a cartoon version of what eventually became Peter Jackson's Treebeard), we are told that Frodo and Sam are entering Mordor, and the Battle of Helm's Deep is won by the Free Peoples. LOTR then slams shut like an iron door.The film is voiced by an all-British cast (including John Hurt as Aragorn), and where it works, it works wonderfully. The traditional animation is smooth and flowing and seamless. Bakshi also decided to use a technique called rotoscoping in which live-action shots are animated in layover. Bakshi at first intended to rotoscope the whole film.The use of rotoscoping was a groundbreaking cinematic development and earned Bakshi's LOTR a place in the history books. As an aside, Peter Jackson also used some rotoscoping in his LOTR, but the advances in technology between 1978 and 2003 mean that Jackson's rotoscoping was flawless. Unfortunately, Bakshi's was not, primarily because of budget constraints, and it sometimes looks rushed, muddy and distracting.  Later critics have attacked Bakshi's work for its flaws, but much of the problem can be laid at the door of studio beancounters.Considering that Bakshi's LOTR cost just over $3,000,000 to make and gated $30,000,000, it is bizarre that the studio did not order up a sequel. Bakshi later disavowed his LOTR. There's a story there that's yet to be told.  Rankin-Bass, who'd previously done an animated THE HOBBIT for television eventually did create an animated made-for-TV THE RETURN OF THE KING calling it the sequel, but it is very different in sense and substance than Bakshi's work, which, despite its shortcomings, is brilliant in spots, and well worth your time, especially if you are a Tolkien fan.

reviewText: Ralph Bakshi's "The Lord of the Rings" is one of those flawed but generally absorbing movies whose legacy seems to be that it was better than nothing, and even that point is hotly debated.  I think this may well be the "Gulliver's Travels" of our generation, an animated film with a unique visual style that sets it apart from its contemporaries because of the innovative technique of rotoscoping, i.e., filming live actors and lying animation over the top.  Cleary Bakshi was trying to avoid using the same visual style as he had employed for "The Hobbit," which, ironically, he returned to when he filmed "The Return of the King."For those few people who do not know, "The Lord of the Rings" adapts the first half of J. R. R. Tolkien's epic tale of the War of the Ring.  Consequently the film ends, rather suddenly, in the middle of "The Two Towers."  When you remember that each volume of the trilogy consists of two "books," then Bakshi animated five-sixths of the three books in two different animation styles.The adaptation, written by Peter S. Beagle and Chris Conkling, is an example of ruthless streamlining (then again, this one at least has an Ent).  Watching this is comparable to watching the original film version of "Dune," where your love of the book fills in the errors and omissions as you go merrily along.  But for the most part this film races along like the Fellowship running through the mines of Moria, so you really have to know the story to keep up.  The standard joke is that this is like the Cliffs Notes version of "The Lord of the Rings," but I have to tell you, the little yellow book with the black stripes has much more details than this movie.The rotoscope process really does not bother me all that much.  It was a novel approach to the problems of telling such an epic story told in the dark days before computers made such things a piece of cake.  If Bakshi had been able to experiment with it more on some other film, then he might have been able to do some more creative work on this film.  On the other hand, I have just never been able to get used to Aragorn looking for all the world like a Native American and Samwise Gamgee looking (and acting) so much like a total buffoon.  The movie also suffers from a rather abrupt ending, more appropriate to a serial than a 133-minute film that falsely promises "to be continued..."In the final analysis, I find that there is really nothing to recommend this film beyond its love for the source material.  I know there are those who want to toss Bakshi into the fires of Mount Doom, but he made an effort and whatever fault people want to find with his thinking in making this film, I am never going to be convinced that his heart was not in the right place.  Maybe he should have stuck to the original animation approach; certainly the film would have benefited from John Huston's gravely voiced Gandalf and I always thought he did a nice job in "The Return of the King" with my favorite scene in the trilogy, when Eowyn fights the Lord of the Nazgul.  Then again, just remember what animation was like way back when in the Seventies and put this effort in some historical context.I do not hate this version of "The Lord of the Rings," mainly because I was never bitterly disappointed by it, which seems to be the key factor.  I remember how we all discussed the many flaws of the film as we were walking out of the theater, but we were rather happy that at least somebody had tried.  Peter Jackson has made all of this moot, but please note that took several decades before it came to pass.  Maybe the charm I find in this film is entirely residue from the Trilogy itself, but I have to admit it is still there for me.
summary: Ralph Bakshi's flawed attempt to bring LOTR to the screen

reviewText: Without Ralph Bakshi's flop of an adaptation, Peter Jackson might not have had the opportunity to deliver his grand adaptation. Bakshi's failure meant that no one wanted to touch LOTR for decades, not until Jackson took up the challenge. So in that sense, I thank Bakshi for making this movie.But beyond that, I can't recommend this to anyone, Tolkien fan or not.Those who favor the movie cite the fact that much more of Tolkien's dialog is preserved here, and scenes from the book are more accurately depicted here than in Jackson's work. Well and good. But that does not make for a good film.Bakshi had no sense of character or story-telling in making this movie, no sense of how to depict Middle-Earth or its inhabitants. This is clear in how he drew and characterized many of the central characters. Aragorn becomes an Apache Chief; Elves apparently originated in 1973 Southern California; Boromir is a Viking; and Sam is a hand-flapping imbecile who happens to wander around in bushes at night (don't ask). All of the hobbits, in fact, have an annoying habit of flapping their hands around as if they have nothing better to do with them. We don't get any sense of why characters are doing what they're doing - they simply do them because the book says they do.Bakshi also has no sense of story-telling. I think he was hoping that the story would tell itself, simply by lifting Tolkien's words off the page and pasting them onto film. But all Bakshi accomplished was a cut-and-paste version of LOTR, not a coherent story. Things simply happen because the book says they happen - we don't really get a sense of why.Watch it if you must, but don't buy it. Watch it because it will help you appreciate Jackson's trilogy. But don't expect to be inspired to read the original books by watching this movie. You might actually decide never to bother with the books.

reviewText: This production, on the surface at least, should have had a lot going for it.  Prior to the advent of convincing computerized special effects, J.R.R. Tolkien's "The Lord of the Rings" was an obvious and natural candidate for translation to an animated feature.  The array of talent assembled for it was formidable, especially the voice actors, who represent the one consistent bright spot in the film.  Peter S. Beagle, one of the scriptwriters, was and is a fine fantasy author in his own right with a deep appreciation for Tolkien.  Even Ralph Bakshi, despite the seeming conflict between his counterculture subversiveness and Tolkien's mainstream Christian leanings, wasn't an entirely bad choice as director.  In the end, though, it is rather difficult to convey fully just how awful this animated feature is.But I'll try.  Let's start with the most glaring deficiency:  midway through the production, they ran out of money.  The movie ends abruptly with part of "The Two Towers" and all of "The Return of the King" left to come.  As anyone who knows the first thing about Tolkien's "trilogy" can tell you, it isn't really a trilogy, but a single book split for the sake of convenience into three volumes.  So, everything is left hanging, nothing is resolved, and there is no sequel to turn to or anticipate.Beyond this, the story is, perhaps by necessity, compressed to such a degree that much of what results is incoherent.  I can't imagine that anyone who is not intimately familiar with the book could make any sense of this.  I can't imagine anyone not irrationally enamored of the book having any appreciation for the stilted, awkward dialogue, either.  Despite some fine voice talent, and the hand of Peter S. Beagle, the script is genuinely terrible.  The conventional animation sequences are occasionally interspersed with live-action footage that has been colored over (so-called "rotoscoping"), which is, to say the least, distracting; to say more, it's genuinely ugly.  Although I can imagine that this technique has its own aficionados, I am not one of them.  The score is equivalent in quality to that of the average 1970s Saturday morning cartoon, mostly consisting of cheap-sounding, staccato horns.It isn't all bad.  The voices are perfect (frankly, I prefer John Hurt's voice to Viggo Mortenson's image as Aragorn), and there are occasional scenes that stick out as particularly effective or genuine-Frodo's reunion with Bilbo at Rivendell, for example.  It is easy to envision a fine comic book (or graphic novel, if you wish to call it that) derived from selected stills of this film.  And for purists, this version is far truer to the book than the newer live-action version directed by Peter Jackson-no blown-up role for Arwen here-although it still leaves a great deal out.  None of these assets come close to canceling out the dreadfulness of the production as a whole, however.  If you're interested in "The Lord of the Rings," read the books, read commentaries on them, even see the Peter Jackson-directed features if you want, but avoid this film.

reviewText: Watching this movie was an incredibly enjoyable experience for me. I was spellbound; I couldn't wait to see how all my favorite moments in the books were played out. Hearing all the great dialogue from the book was a real pleasure. I realized how much of it I really missed when I watched the Peter Jackson adaptions. Don't get me wrong, those movies are my all-time favorites, just as the books have always surpassed all others for me; but come on. Don't you miss seeing Frodo actually draw his sword and attempt to stand up to the black riders instead of falling backwards without a fight? And the wonderful humorous moments that lightened the series' mood near the beginning were sadly missing in the Peter Jackson films as well. Then too, some of the most chilling moments in the books, such as the flight to the ford, were really softened in the newer movies. Not so with Bakshi's! The creepy red contrasts and blaring music definitely capture the necessary terror of the black riders' chase. Yet, while the music is good, it does not often tell you how to feel; sometimes I think newer movies are always trying to make you feel a certain way about the characters and happenings, whereas this movie tells you what happens in the story and lets you decide what you think, rather like a book.This movie is not flawless; sometimes a great line from the book is cut short, no doubt for time purposes, but still, I missed it. Thoughts from the book aren't always carried out to their conclusions.Sam seemed a bit too oafish, but everyone imagines things differently when they read a book. I thought Frodo was done very well, and so was Aragorn; in the book he was described as rather rough-looking.I was grossly disappointed when the movie ended part-way through The Two Towers and I learned there was no sequel. I would really have liked to see how Bakshi visualized the rest. Still, this much is definitely worth a watch, despite the disappointment of its ending; it's great to find another way to experience Tolkien's work.

reviewText: This film is apparently loved by people who preferred a version closer to the books than Peter Jackson's, as well as Arwen-haters who were furious that someone with boobs dare have her role inflated for a LOTR movie (but who were perfectly fine with all the battle-action added in for the male heroes).  That's pretty much the only positive thing to be said for this movie; it was closer to the books. Assuming that "closer to the book" is always, automatically a good thing.Before I go on, I'll establish my credibility here. I've read "Fellowship" and "Two Towers," and (mostly) enjoyed them. I've read parts of "Return of the King" and plan to read the whole trilogy eventually. And of course I've seen Peter Jackson's trilogy more times than I can count.  I've read "The Hobbit." I'm not the most devoted, hardcore fan, but I do like LOTR, a lot. I am also a very hardcore fan of animation, and a big fan of Ralph Bakshi's (the man who made this animated film).And now, for my humble, subjective opinion: this movie sucks.  At times, the suckiness is entertaining. But mostly it's just painful.PLOT:Very close to the books. Oddly, This film deals only with "The Fellowship of the Ring" and "The Two Towers," rather than following the book's trilogy model, or cramming them all into one film. Some small changes are made (like having Legolas replace Glorfindel in one scene), but it's far closer to the books than the famous Jackson version.CHARACTERS:Some are very close to the book. Frodo and Aragorn come to mind. Others...aren't. Poor Sam was lobotomized for this movie. And Treebeard was a giant walking carrot with feet--although, this was one of those things that was so dumb it made me laugh. He seemed like he'd fit better in "The Phantom Tollbooth."As for the characters who were close to the book, they might've been a bit too close. Jackson's version put twists on the characters. He made Aragorn conflicted about becoming king, fearing that the power would corrupt him like it did his ancestor; Jackson's Frodo was vulnerable, and conflicted about carrying the ring. This movie on the other hand puts no interpretative twist on the characters.  They just march into the quest like it's something they do every day. "Okay, lets' get this ring thing over with, so I can go home and have a beer already."Oh, and forget about female characters. Galadriel has a nice cameo, but that's it. Arwen is completely absent. Eowyn is present, but mute. Oh, and Aragorn tells that story to the hobbits, about the elf who gave her immortality up for the man she loved; but with no sight or mention of Arwen, that scene becomes pointless.  On the other hand, knowing Ralph Bakshi, maybe it's better that the women didn't show up; Arwen would probably have some sheer stripperiffic gown that showed her nipples, and Eowyn would fight in a spiraled metal bikini.ANIMATION:Lazy. Horribly, insultingly, appallingly, hilariously, depressingly, maddeningly lazy.The opening scene is so badly done, you'd think it was a comedy that was being cheap on purpose.  We open to a series of silhouettes against a red backdrop.  It's obviously live "actors", but I think we're supposed to be fooled into thinking they're just silhouettes of the animated characters we'll meet later. Or maybe it's just another example of Bakshi's experimental style of mixing live action with animation.  You'll see a lot of that in this movie.The live-action returns later on, in the form of rotoscoping...if that's even the right term to describe it. The Black Riders and Orcs seem like live-action footage of people in silly costumes, tinted black, and then poorly spliced over the animated scenes. (The Orcs also have silly Muppet fangs.) The Prancing Pony is filled with live-action peasants, crudely drawn and inked over, looking far too realistic, spliced over the animated backdrop and interacting with the cartoon bartender and hobbits.  Perhaps most hysterical is the Balrog, a live-action man in a black lion/dragon costume, who comes stopping in like something from a `60s Japanese monster flick.The main characters are more traditionally animated, but still rotoscoped. They way they move is very wobbly, and makes me a tad dizzy as I type this, just thinking about it.And finally, the character designs. They're bland and best, and absurd at worst. Okay, I realize that animation was more difficult in 1978, and they couldn't make the characters appearances or clothing too detailed. But they still could've done something...creative. Animated films before this one did better, and Bakshi himself has done better. Nothing about the elves looks magical; they don't look particularly more "beautiful" than humans, and don't even have pointed ears. There is a disturbing lack of pants amongst the human and elf male leads. Oh, and Boromir, for some reason, is a goddamn Viking.There are two good things about the animation. One, that the backgrounds are often quite detailed and lovely, often filled with weird faces that remind one of Bakshi's "Cool World." Two, there are a few instances of surreal, colorful lights swimming about, just to remind you that this movie is from the '70s.Ralph Bakshi has a very unique way of doing animation. The weird mix of animation and live action does work in his other films ("Cool World," "Coonskin," "Heavy Traffic," "Wizards"), because those movies are supposed to be outrageous. They're half-comedy, half-social commentary. When he tried to do something more mainstream with LOTR though, it didn't work.  At all.ACTING/DIRECTING:Dull. I assume the director is more responsible than the actors, but I'm not interested in throwing blame here. I'm just here to say that this movie isn't very dramatic.Galadriel is never tempted by the ring; instead, her "In place of a dark lord..." speech is turned into a sarcastic joke. Boromir comes close to adding drama when he's acting out, but that horned Viking helmet makes it impossible to talk him seriously. I've already mentioned Sam's mental castration, and the rest of the cast's indifference towards their quest.MUSIC:In truth, I don't remember the soundtrack. I was far too distracted by the bizarre and mind-numbing visuals.  BUT, I did hear on an interview with Bakshi, that he originally wanted to play his LOTR film against hippie-rock music. Now THAT might have made for an interesting movie.THE SEQUEL:In case you're a masochist, and want MORE of this turkey, there is a sequel, "The Return of the King," that continues the adventure.  I looked it up out of curiosity, and found that it was released in 1980, on TV only. Yes. Bakshi's film was a legitimate movie, and the sequel wasn't. Which can only mean that ROTK is. Even. Cheaper. I watched the clip on You Tube of Eowyn slaying the Witch King. It was hilarious. He sounded like the Monarch from "Venture Bros."THE GOOD BITS:Even a heckler must admit that there are a few good things about this movie. I shall list them:* The Proudfoot hobbit shouting, "ProudFEET!" and wiggling his toes, in a funny way.* Treebeard. His appearance and walk are a riot. He will make you nostalgic for "The Phantom Tollbooth" and "Looney Tunes."* Trippy Disco lights flying out of Saruman's cloak and Galadirel's ring* The Orcs are pretty funny looking. They look like black Muppets, with fangs stolen right from The Count and horns stolen from "Eureka's Castle."* Sam's idiocy is often so awful it's funny. "OOoooo Mr. Frodoooo, I'm drowning!"* Legolas 's derpy cross-eyed face. He looks high 24/7.* Gandalf's drama-queen twirls and bug-eyes are hilarious, and at times remind me of Merlin from Disney's "The Sword in the Stone."  (There's a lot in this movie that brings out the kid in you.)THE FINAL LAMENT:There is one thing that makes me horribly sad about Ralph Bakshi doing LOTR. More-so than anything else previously mentioned. It's the fact that he did "Lord of the Rings," and not "Bored of the Rings." "Bored of the Rings" is an outrageous parody of LOTR, written in 1969 by the Harvard Lampoon. If anyone could pull off that cartoonish, crude, 60s-pop-culture-filled comedy, it's Bakshi. It pains me that he tried to do something serious with LOTR, when he could've done something ingenious with BOTR.  BUT, what movies Bakshi wanted to make are none of my beeswax.

reviewText: When I went and saw this movie during opening weekend, it was standing room only in the brown eggshell that used to be the century theatre architecture.  My friend and I bought tickets, walked in, and there were, quite literally, people standing in the back isled behind the back row of seats, and people standing on the side by the emergency exit to see this thing.  I mean, wow, the movie must be really good for this kind of turnout.Imagine my disappointment when the film was over.  I may be unique in that I was exposed to Tolkien while I was still in first and second grade many years earlier, but even the adults who walked out of that theatre left silent.  After the film was over no one had much to say.The film resembled Tolkien's work in that the main characters were present, the first half of the film was dedicated to "The Fellowship of the Ring", and that's about it.  All of the other story elements were gone.  Literally, they were just not present.  And that became that TALK of the film.  "This was missing...."  "They didn't show that..." and similar phrases were bandied about.What had gone wrong?  The official story is that Bakshi ran out of money.  I'm sure that's mostly true.  But I can't help but feel that no one wanted to create this project in the first place for some odd, stupid, and fearfully silly social-psychological reason.  What the fear was, I don't know, and won't even venture to speculate, but thank goodness Peter Jackson came along and did a fantastic epic and proper retelling of one of the great sagas of literature.Technical aspects of the film aren't all that impressive.  It seems like a lot of the budget was spent on the first half of the film, and then once the money started running out the film was rushed with a lot of rotoscoping.  Note that the first half of the film has very sumptuous backgrounds and respectable animation, while the back end of the film is wanting in production values.  Disney it ain't.A lot of movies (most American films that is) are geared toward social psychology of keeping healthy images and feelings coursing through society.  One wonders if there was a negative feeling that Tolkien's tale conveyed that the mental-health types were afraid to put entirely onscreen, and only did so in this half-baked effort.  Either way, the film falls apart half way through, and does not deliver at the end.  We don't see what happens to the ring.  The two main characters vanish into mist with Gollumn, and their wizard winds up leading the army to save middle earth.  But, that's not how Tolkien's books ended.I saw it once when I was younger, and once was enough.  Then I bought a cheap DVD years back, saw it, was reminded of why I only saw the movie once, and then put it away.  I then organized my DVDs and contemplated watching it again, but held off, and instead decided to write this review.Give me an animation team, and I can deliver a Lord of the Rings film with all the aplomb of Jackson, AND I'll keep all the characters and all the story points without shaving stuff, unlike Jackson's two very wonderful and talented lady screenwriters.  As for Bakshii, well, maybe he can do another Catskill's animation film about how a Jewish family escaped Nazi Germany, fought prejudice here in the US, and went on to become big successes in the entertainment industry.  Oh wait, has that been done...to death?  *sarmcasm*.In any event, skip this movie.  See Jackson's rendition--done by a man who knows and loves the material like so many fans, and has the talent to bring together a film to tell the tale on the big screen.

reviewText: Before Peter Jackson worked his live-action and computer-enhanced magic on Tolkein's fantasy epic, animator Ralph Bakshi created a mostly hand-drawn version that is new again in a crisp, clean Blu-ray edition.Intended as Part One of the grand Hobbit mythos, Bakshi never made the sequel.  However, this stand-alone excerpt of the bigger story has its charms - and its fans.For part of a summer, I worked on this film.  The studio was set up in one of the upper floors of a high-rise bank building located on the corner of Sunset Blvd. and Vine St.I especially remember the fabricating of the exquisite background art and the work-in-progress production design by famed illustrator and concept artist Ron Cobb.  I was hoping to do background work but was assigned animation.  Previous to the actual animation start, Bakshi shot the entire film in black and white with actors on a sound stage.  Enlargements of the frames were used as "guides" for the artists who would then hand-draw -- kind of trace -- the film characters over the frames of the lives-action sequences.  This rotoscoping process renders some of the scenes with an uncanny life-like appearance that adds immeasurably to the tone of the epic.  (I remember doing a difficult sequence of Gandalf on a running horse.  It's still in the movie.)  However, the infrequent use of overt optical and photographic effects laid onto the animation is startling.  I remember Bakshi as a loud, unfiltered, driven, brilliant Brooklyn artist who had an urgent vision that he was compelled to put on the screen.  I liked him immensely, even though my stay was short-lived.
summary: BAKSHI'S BODACIOUS VISION IN BEAUTIFUL BLU-RAY
